The layout Module¶

Layouts determine how objects are displayed in a Window. The base class “Layout” requires all content items to specify their position in the Layout manually. Other subclasses of “Layout” will attempt to lay the contents out automatically.

class pylablib.layout.Clickable(app, batch=None, x=0, y=0, width=None, height=None, align=[], border=0)¶
If you want the layout itself to respond to events, use Clickable
class pylablib.layout.Cue(window, cue='+')¶
display a cue on the screen
class pylablib.layout.Flow(app, batch=None, x=0, y=0, width=None, height=None, align=[], border=0)¶

Flow introduce the idea of: automatically laying out the elements in self.contents

use self.has_handlers to enable/disable Clickable per instance

get_dimensions(max_x=None, max_y=None)¶

go through all elements in content and determine total dimensions of all content

in this context, cur_x and cur_y start in the uppper left hand corner

this version describes the layout of a Flow Slot

render_contents(x, y)¶

defines the render method of a Flow Slot

recursively render each elment in contents add it to the element’s batch

requires self.batch to be set on initialization for each element

also requires that all elements’ dimensions have been found and set including our own

class pylablib.layout.Layout(app, batch=None, x=0, y=0, width=None, height=None, align=[], border=0)¶

Layouts require the position and dimensions of all elements to be manually specified

layouts have no event handlers associated with them this makes them static

if you want the layout to respond to events, use Clickable, which is a subclass of Layout.

add_item(item)¶
add the item to our contents and update that item’s batch to be the same as ours should check if the batch is the same first to avoid re-assigning the same one (batch re-assignment is a potentially expensive operation according to pyglet docs: pyglet/doc/html/api/pyglet.sprite.Sprite-class.html
build(x=None, y=None)¶
draw(x=None, y=None)¶
update if we’ve moved, otherwise draw what has been rendered to batch
get_dimensions(max_x=None, max_y=None)¶
for a manually defined set of dimensions
pop_handlers()¶
only pop handlers for elements in contents (static layout doesn’t have handlers personally)
push_handlers()¶
only push handlers for elements in contents (static layout doesn’t have handlers personally)
render_background()¶
most layouts will probably want this... no need to redefine in every different render_contents method
render_contents(x, y)¶

render a manually defined Layout elements in contents are rendered relative to our position

recursively render each elment in contents add it to the element’s batch

requires self.batch to be set on initialization for each element

also requires that all elements’ dimensions have been found and set including ours

set_dimensions(width=None, height=None)¶

initialize the layout’s dimensions used to set a layout to be the same dimensions as the app and make those dimensions fixed

sets self.fixed to true aka fix_dimensions

unload()¶
this cleans up memory
update_dimensions(actual_width, actual_height)¶
only update our dimensions (with what was sent) if we’re not a fixed_size otherwise ok to update those values that are not currently set
class pylablib.layout.Row(app, batch=None, x=0, y=0, width=None, height=None, align=[], border=0)¶

one row of elements

rows are used internally for rendering a Flow

items in contents are layed out left to right

align is either top, center or bottom

get_dimensions(max_x=None, max_y=None)¶
should have already determined if elements could fit in row
render_contents(x, y)¶

defines the render method of a Row

recursively render each elment in contents requires self.batch to be set on initialization for each element

class pylablib.layout.Stack(app, batch=None, x=0, y=0, width=None, height=None, align=[], border=0)¶

Responds to events like a Flow but uses a different algorithm to lay the elements in contents out... one on top of another instead of left to right.

get_dimensions(max_x=None, max_y=None)¶

go through all elements in content and determine total dimensions of all content

in this context, x and y start in the uppper left hand corner

describes the layout of a Stack

render_contents(x, y)¶

defines the render method of a Stack

recursively render each elment in contents

requires self.batch to be set on initialization for each element

class pylablib.layout.WindowLayout(app, batch=None, x=0, y=0, width=None, height=None, align=[], border=0)¶

assumes that this is the main/parent/root layout and performs initialization and render operations as needed for root layouts
